channel.title: The Arm Engine
channel.description:
[size=4]Well, I recently decided to develop a complete high end advanced 3D engine that can render in DirectX and OpenGL, ofcourse this won't be something to make in 1 2 and 3.[/size]
[size=4]I have 2 years time to complete this engine because of the fact that 2 years is what is left for me to go to DAE (Digital Arts and Entertainment). This engine will become very handy in the future.[/size]
[size=4]I will also probably assemble a team together for when the engine is completed, and make the next Call of Duty.[/size]
[size=4]This engine will be completely written in C++ and I will try to use as few libraries as possible.[/size] [size=4]The main reason I'm doing this project is because I want to turn into a C++ guru and the only way to do that is by doing a big project like this one and learning on the go. I know this technique works because I have done projects like this in the past to learn Flash, ofcourse this is on a totally different scale and will take A LOT of time. So atm, I'm just doing a lot of research on C++, using the high end 3D API's, how other people wrote 3D engines,... To get a basic POV of what I will go trough.[/size]
[size=4]After that I'll start writing a basic 3D shitty graphical game, add more and more advanced functions to the shitty game, and evantually turn that game into an engine and start doing some serious work.[/size]
[size=4]All my progress will be documented within this topic and I will try to document as much as possible on how I went forward as this will help a lot of other people trying to do something similar.[/size]
[size=4]My english isn't perfect, I learned it mainly from watching movies and playing runescape when I was younger so excuse me for that but It's understandable.[/size]
[size=4]For those who want to know, this engine will be completely closed source and I will name it Arm Engine, Arm represents my mother country, Armenia. And Engine well, that just represents engine. In other words, Armenian Engine, but the official name will be Arm Engine. So that's that.[/size]
[size=4]Anyhow, we've reached the end of this particular log, so see you soon.[/size]
[size=4]- MistaBigBoss/Vreg[/size] [size=4]_____________________________________________________________________________________ 25 August 2011[/size]

item.title: The Arm Engine
item.dc:creator: @MistaBigBoss MistaBigBoss
item.description:
@MistaBigBoss wrote:

[quote=“Taharok, post:29, topic:412043”]If you want to understand what everyone is saying here…start off smaller. Honestly, you are way over your head. This is something I’ve run into over, and over, and over, and over again. I start massive projects and get a good chunk through until they become overwhelming. You need to have experience with the building blocks, a plan, organizational strategy, and a thorough understanding of what you are trying to accomplish. At that point, it doesn’t matter what the project is, so long as you remain dedicated.

Your shortfall lies with the building blocks part. You are starting to learn C++ and expect to design not only a 3D game engine, not only an advanced and sophisticated 3D game engine, but a game engine with the capability of making a “better call of duty.” You need to take into consideration the sort of capital that goes into developing a game like call of duty. A person who does not even know C++ can’t just wakeup one day and decide to recreate a game better than a team of programmers who have probably had decades of combined professional programming experience.

I am not doubting your capability, but I am doubting your experience. Don’t just shoot down the advice in this thread. It’s given by people who have not only been where you are, but have also made mistakes you are about to. You are basically wasting the majority of your time doing a project like this until you’re ready. I doubt anyone on this website could step forward and complete the goal you just set. I know even triton wouldn’t try it until he was entirely satisfied with his own engine/editor, and had every aspect of the game drawn out to a T so he knew exactly what he was about to go into.

Start simple, build on previous concepts. This is a technique used in schooling systems around the world because it works, duh. Schools don’t assign you massive projects on the first day and expect you to finish it in 2 weeks (because comparatively, that’s the deadline you set yourself). Sure, you might be able to do a 3D engine in 2 years, but it will not be anything like you are expecting. I’d also recommend what frell said about using other engines. If you aren’t happy with them, then make your own. :)[/quote]Thank you, that is definitely some great advice and I might gave you guys the wrong idea about making the next call of duty. It was a joke people, who knows maybe 5-8 years later but probably not.

I didn’t think that people would take that serious. As I stated a couple of times before, I’m satisfied with a shitty prototype that can render some models and allow a camera to view them.

I know, what it takes to make the next Call of Duty, I know because I’ve seen those teams before and whenever playing games like that, I’m always amazed how people can manage to make a game that complex so that’s nothing new, and I have a general idea of how I’m going to make this engine and make it come alive. This will all just be a great learning expirience even if it fails so I don’t really care if it comes out great or not, as long as I learn new languages,…
